Box 60169, Riyadh 11545, Saudi Arabia * Corresponding author The potential of sustainable hydrogen production technology through water splitting necessitates the rational design of oxygen evolution reaction (OER) and hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) bi-functional electrocatalysts. In this context, we initially synthesized and empirically evaluated ultralow Ru-doped NiMoO4@Ni3(PO4)2 core-shell nanostructures on nickel foam (Ru-NiMoO4@Ni3(PO4)2/NF). The hydrous NiMoO4 nanopillars were hydrothermally grown on NF, followed by successive RuCl3 etching and subsequent phosphorylation processes, leading to the final Ru-NiMoO4@Ni3(PO4)2/NF. The catalyst demonstrated impressive HER overpotential values of −14.8 and −57.1 mV at 10 and 100 mA cm−2, respectively, with a Tafel slope of 35.8 mV dec−1. For OER at 100 mA cm−2, an overpotential of 259.7 mV was observed, with a Tafel slope of 21.6 mV dec−1. The cell voltage required for overall water splitting was 1.43 V at 10 mA cm−2 and 1.68 V at 100 mA cm−2. Moreover, the catalyst exhibited superior stability for 150 h, emphasizing its practical utility for long-term applications. Subsequent density functional theory calculations aligned with these empirical findings, indicating a low water dissociation energy barrier (ΔG b = 0.46 eV), near-zero free adsorption energy for HER (ΔG *H = 0.02 eV), and suitable free adsorption energy for OER (ΔG *OOH − ΔG *OH = 2.74 eV), alongside a high density of states near the Fermi level. These results, informed by both experimental evaluation and theoretical validation, highlight the potential of Ru-NiMoO4@Ni3(PO4)2/NF as a high-performance catalyst for water splitting, setting a solid foundation for advancements in sustainable energy technologies. Graphical Abstract Ultralow Ru-doped NiMoO4@Ni3(PO4)2 core-shell nanostructures on nickel foam demonstrate remarkable electrocatalytic activity and stability in oxygen evolution reaction and hydrogen evolution reaction for water splitting. Keywords Electrocatalysis Core-shell structure Doping Density functional theory Hydrogen evolution reaction Oxygen evolution reaction Water splitting 1 Introduction Concerns over energy resource depletion and greenhouse gas emissions from fossil fuels have intensified the pursuit of renewable energy alternatives [1,2]. Among these alternatives, hydrogen, a carbon-neutral and high-energy density renewable source, is a prominent contender to replace fossil fuels. The electrochemical water splitting process is pivotal in this scenario, as it offers a means of producing emission-free high-purity hydrogen; the obtained hydrogen can then be used as chemical fuel to store energy derived from water [3–7]. Electrocatalysts are central to this process, making water splitting an energy-efficient process [8]. Although platinum (Pt) and noble metal oxides such as iridium oxide (IrO2) and ruthenium oxide (RuO2) are top-tier electrocatalysts for the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER), respectively, their limited availability, high cost, and stability issues restrict their widespread adoption [9,10]. Consequently, the search for electrocatalysts made of abundant, affordable elements has led to the exploration of various materials such as transition metal oxides [11], hydroxides [12,13], phosphides [14,15], nitrides [16], carbides [17], sulfides [18], and borides [19]. Nickel-molybdenum (NiMo) materials, including MoNi4 [20], NiMoO4 [21], NiMoN [22], and NiMoP [23], are becoming increasingly used as electrocatalysts for a wide range of energy applications. They utilize the combined power of nickel, characterized by its extensive surface area, electron transfer capabilities, and solution stability, and molybdenum, known for its catalytic ability and H2 adsorption properties. In this framework, NiMoO4 is notable because it tackles the challenges faced by monometallic catalysts in maintaining adsorption-desorption equilibrium. NiMoO4 can be enhanced using the following strategies: (1) integration with conductive substrates, such as nickel foam (NF) [24]; fostering augmented mass transport and reaction kinetics; (2) nanoengineering, which has introduced a suite of structures like heterostructures [25], nanorods [2,26], nanowires [27], nanosheets [26], nanoflowers [28], and nanopillars [22,29] among these NiMoO4 nanostructures; (3) surface modification techniques: where surface modification in metal molybdates has progressed significantly, with particular emphasis on the fabrication of core-shell structures. Examples of such advancements include NiMoO4@Co3O4 [30], NiMoO4@MoSe2/Ni x Se y [31], and NiMoO4@NiFeP [32]. These compounds feature a nickel molybdate core surrounded by various shell materials. This approach has been observed to substantially enhance the catalytic activity of these materials; and (4) doping: the doping modalities, like phosphorus (P) doping in NiMoO4 heterostructures, improve electrical conductivity and catalytic surface reactivity, where the P atom functions as a “proton attractor ” and an “energetic enhancer,” facilitating improved hydrogen adsorption, desorption, and overall electrocatalytic efficiency [25]. Meanwhile, aluminum doping can modify its structure, amplifying the number of active sites and boosting electrochemical performance [33]. Density functional theory (DFT) analyses and experimental results demonstrate that ruthenium (Ru), despite being substantially more cost-effective than Pt, displays a metal-hydrogen bond strength similar to that of Pt [34,35]. Theoretical insights and empirical data indicate that Ru has exceptional adsorption properties for intermediates rich in hydrogen and oxygen [1,36]. Thus, incorporating a proper amount of Ru as a catalyst constituent can markedly bolster catalytic proficiency while preserving economic viability [37]. However, during synthesis, the undesired clustering of Ru negatively affects the catalytic activity and durability [38,39]. To mitigate this issue, researchers should identify affordable and appropriate substrates for the precise dispersion and size control of Ru nanoparticles, and they should engineer novel hybrid materials that foster a synergistic interplay between Ru and these substrates. In this study, we embarked on the synthesis and empirical testing of Ru-doped NiMoO4@Ni3(PO4)2 core-shell nanostructures on NF (Ru-NiMoO4@Ni3(PO4)2/NF), focusing on their application in HER and OER. The catalyst was created through hydrothermal growth of hydrous NiMoO4 nanopillars on NF, followed by subsequent treatments. The innovative aspect of our work is highlighted in the subsequent treatment of these nanopillars. Initially, we applied a methodical etching process with ultra-low concentrations of Ru. After the etching step, the nanopillars were subjected to phosphorylation to introduce PO4 ions, forming a Ni3(PO4)2 shell. Ru distributed across the core-shell structure enhances catalytic performance and overcomes previous design limitations such as Ru clustering. DFT calculations were then performed, confirming the practical findings by showing near-zero free energy for hydrogen adsorption (ΔG *H) and low Gibbs free energy (ΔG b) for OER and water dissociation. The alignment of DFT results with empirical data reinforced the efficacy of the Ru-NiMoO4@Ni3(PO4)2/NF catalyst in enhancing catalytic performance. This balanced and harmonious configuration of materials in our catalyst sets a new standard in the fields of HER, OER, and overall water splitting, showcasing our approach as a notable advancement in nanostructured catalyst design. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Nickel foam (NF) (thickness: 1.6 mm, bulk density: 0.58 g cm−3, pore size: 0.1 mm, number of pores per inch: 90) was acquired from Kunshan Longshengbao Electronic Materials Co., Ltd. Chemicals including ammonium molybdate tetrahydrate ((NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O, 98%), ruthenium chloride hydrate (RuCl3·xH2O, 35.0%–42.0% Ru basis), potassium hydroxide (KOH, 95%), sodium hypophosphite monohydrate (NaH2PO2·H2O, ≥99%), and ruthenium (IV) oxide (RuO2, 99.9%) were obtained from Shanghai Aladdin Bio-Chem Technology Co., Ltd. Nickel (II) nitrate hexahydrate (Ni(NO3)2·6H2O, 99%) were purchased from Tianjin Damao Chemical Reagent. Commercial Pt/C (20% Pt on Vulcan XC-72) was sourced from Alfa Aesar. No additional purification was carried out on the chemicals and reagents. 2.2 Preparation of catalysts 2.2.1 Synthesis of NiMoO4 precursor To prepare the NiMoO4 nanopillar precursor on NF (2.9 × 5 cm2), an initial ultrasonic cleaning in 3 mol L−1 hydrochloric acid for half an hour was performed to strip the oxide layer. This was followed by a 20-min ethanol soak and numerous deionized (DI) water rinses. The cleaned NF was then submerged vertically in a 50 mL Teflon container, filled with a 40 mL aqueous solution containing 0.04 mol L−1 of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O and 0.01 mol L−1 of (NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O. The Teflon vessel was subsequently sealed in a stainless-steel autoclave and maintained at a temperature of 160 °C for 6 h. After cooling to ambient temperature, the acquired yellow precursor was subjected to multiple rinses in ethanol and DI water and was left to dry overnight at 60 °C. The resulting material was identified as NiMoO4/NF precursor. 2.2.2 Synthesis of Ru-NiMoO4@Ni3(PO4)2/NF The target composite, Ru-NiMoO4@Ni3(PO4)2/NF, was fabricated through a sequential process involving Ru3+ etching and gentle phosphating. Initially, a 1 × 1 cm2 piece of NiMoO4/NF precursor was soaked in a 50 mL water solution containing 100 mg of RuCl3·xH2O (concentration: 2 mg mL−1) for 2 h. Post-soak, the sample was rinsed with ethanol and DI water and air-dried. Subsequently, the dried sample was positioned at the mid-section of a tube furnace, with 300 mg of NaH2PO2 situated upstream. A thermal phosphorylation process ensued at 300 °C with a heating rate of 2 °C min−1 in an Ar gas atmosphere for 2 h. Once the furnace naturally cooled to room temperature, the final Ru-NiMoO4@Ni3(PO4)2 product was retrieved, rinsed, and dried. The loading of Ru-NiMoO4@Ni3(PO4)2, exclusive of NF, was approximately 4 mg cm−2. For comparison, additional experiments were conducted with varying soaking times (15, 30, 45 min, 1, 3, 4, and 5 h), as well as at different solution concentrations of 6 and 10 mg mL−1 at a soaking time of 2 h. 2.2.3 Synthesis of Ru-NiMoO4/NF The synthesis of Ru-NiMoO4 followed the same procedure as Ru-NiMoO4@Ni3(PO4)2, except that NaH2PO2 was not involved in the thermal process. 2.2.4 Synthesis of NiMoO4/NF NiMoO4/NF was synthesized by positioning the NiMoO4/NF precursor at the tube furnace's center. Thermal processing was carried out at 300 °C with a heating ramp of 2 °C min−1 in an argon atmosphere for 2 h. 2.2.5 Preparation of RuO2 and Pt/C catalysts on NF For comparative purposes, a RuO2/NF electrode was crafted by dispersing 40 mg of RuO2 and 60 µL of Nafion in a solvent mix of 540 µL ethanol and 400 µL DI water. After a 30-min ultrasonic treatment, the resulting dispersion was coated onto an NF substrate and left to air-dry overnight. Pt/C electrodes were fabricated in a similar manner. 2.3 Materials characterization Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were obtained on a Rigaku D/MAXRC X-ray diffractometer using a Cu Kα radiation source (40.0 kV, 40.0 mA). The surface morphologies of the samples were characterized by a scanning electron microscopy (SEM, FEI Quanta 200S). Transmission electron microscopy, Selected Area Electron Diffraction (TEM, SAED, JEOL JEM-2100F) and EDS spectrometer model (SUPER-X EDX) were applied to analyze the microstructure, crystallographic orientation, and elemental composition of the synthesized nanoparticles. Raman spectra were collected with a confocal Raman spectroscopic system (Renishaw, InVia) using a 532 nm laser with a TE air-cooled 576 × 400 CCD array as the excitation source. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was carried out on an ESCA Lab MKII X-ray photoelectron spectrometer using Al Kα radiation as an excitation source (hυ = 1486.6 eV). The Inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES) was performed on a Thermo Scientific iCAP PRO. 2.4 Electrode preparation and electrochemical measurement Electrochemical experiments were conducted using a standard three-electrode configuration employing the CHI660E electrochemical workstation. The synthesized samples on Ni foam (1 × 1 cm2), namely Ru-NiMoO4@Ni3(PO4)2/NF, NiMoO4@Ni3(PO4)2/NF, NiMoO4/NF, Pt/C/NF, and RuO2/NF, acted as the working electrode. Meanwhile, a highly pure graphite rod (Alfa Aesar, 99.999%) functioned as the counter electrode. Electrochemical tests took place in a 1.0 mol L−1 KOH solution, and resultant data underwent iR-correction. Linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) was employed with a scan rate of 2 mV s−1 to prevent capacitive current formation during the electrocatalytic process. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was executed over a frequency span of 106–0.01 Hz with a 5 mV amplitude at potentials of –0.94 V for the HER and 0.57 V for the OER. The series resistance from EIS data facilitated corrections for the ohmic loss, optimizing the comparative analysis of the catalysts’ activity. iR compensation followed the relation E(iR) = E(Hg/HgO) – iR [40]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Morphological and structural characterizations The synthesis of the 3D Ru-NiMoO4@Ni3(PO4)2/NF core-shell nanopillar architectures was carried out via a hierarchical strategy. This process commenced with the hydrothermal generation of NiMoO4, followed by precise etching involving Ru and forming Ni3(PO4)2 through phosphorylation (Fig. 1(a) ). The formation of NiMoO4 nanopillars on NF and the subsequent deposition of Ru and phosphorylation to create a Ru-NiMoO4@Ni3(PO4)/NF composite could be observed based on changes in color, as shown in Fig. S1. The synthesis of pure NiMoO4 resulted in the formation of vertically aligned, smooth nanopillars with a high aspect ratio, as clearly depicted in the field emission scanning electron microscope images (Figs. 1(b) and 1(c)). Upon the sequential application of Ru etching and phosphorylation, the resultant Ru-NiMoO4@Ni3(PO4)2/NF maintained the original architecture of the nanopillars (Figs. 1(d) and 1(e)), implying the efficacy of the adopted procedures in nanopillar growth, etching, and shell formation. The magnified SEM image in Fig. 1(e) revealed a change in the surface topography; the introduction of doping and phosphorylation led to a uniform surface, which enhanced its roughness and consequently gave it a porous texture. The presence of a porous structure played a crucial role in promoting the effectiveness of charge transfer and mass transport throughout the catalytic reaction. Fig. S2 displays the SEM images illustrating the gradual doping of Ru on Ru-NiMoO4/NF nanopillars at various immersion times and solution concentrations. Initially, the doping of Ru facilitated controlled Ru distribution but led to unwanted Ru accumulation at high concentrations. TEM analyses offer an essential perspective into the structural complexities of the materials being studied. The TEM images of the Ru-NiMoO4@Ni3(PO4)2 nanopillar revealed a clear alteration in their morphology, with their diameter increasing from 418 nm to 677 nm (Figs. 1(f) and S5(a,b)). By contrast, the pristine NiMoO4 structure displayed organized nanopillars with smooth facets. The diameter of these pillars ranged from 362 to 557 nm (Figs. S4(a), S4(b), S4(d), S4(f), and S4(h)). The evident increase in the nanopillar diameter of Ru-NiMoO4@Ni3(PO4)2, when compared with NiMoO4, showcased the alterations due to shell formation (Fig. 1(g)). Subsequent investigations employing HR-TEM further elucidated the structural details. The HR-TEM images (Fig. 1(h)) and their corresponding Fast Fourier Transform (FFT) images (Fig. 1(i)) of the Ru-NiMoO4@Ni3(PO4)2 sample revealed diverse interplanar spacings. The spacing measured at 0.652 nm, corresponded to the (100) lattice plane of hydrous NiMoO4, whereas that at 0.342 nm was correlated with the (111) lattice plane of Ni3(PO4)2. This unique structural arrangement was posited to enhance the electrochemical performance of the composite by facilitating electron transfer among the three components. The unaltered NiMoO4, as depicted in Figs. S4(c), S4(e), S4(g), S4(i), and S4(j), exhibited typical interplanar spacings of 0.899, 0.325, 0.284, 0.236, and 0.198 nm, corresponding to the (001), (020), (212), (-2-21), and (-1-23) lattice planes of hydrous NiMoO4 that aligned with previous X-ray diffraction (XRD) analyses, respectively. In the analysis of the SAED pattern for the Ru-NiMoO4@Ni3(PO4)2 composite (inset of Fig. 1(h)), we found clear dots grouped in lines, representing the single-crystal areas, superimposed on diffraction rings, which indicated the polycrystalline regions. The interplanar spacings observed in these dots corresponded to the known crystallographic data for Ni3(PO4)2 and NiMoO4·nH2O. Specifically, the dots on planes such as (100) for NiMoO4·nH2O appeared in the form of parallel straight lines, indicating a single-crystal sample. This observation was also corroborated by the SAED images of hydrous NiMoO4 (inset of Figs. S4(c), S4(e), and S4(i)). Furthermore, the presence of the (111) and (-211) planes for Ni3(PO4)2 indicated another dimension of the structural composition of the composite, suggesting the occurrence of many orientations within the crystalline matrix. Moreover, the presence of these planes in a ring-like configuration indicated that the composite was polycrystalline. Fig. 1(j) presents a series of high-angle annular dark field (HAADF) images coupled with energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) elemental line scans and mapping, showcasing the structural and compositional characteristics of Ru-NiMoO4@Ni3(PO4)2 nanopillars. Two distinct nanopillars were analyzed, each revealing critical insights into the material's morphology and elemental distribution. The panels display the HAADF images and corresponding EDS line scan of the first nanopillar. The HAADF images suggested a diverse distribution of elements or differences in material thickness. The EDS line scan traversed the length of the nanopillar, displaying peaks corresponding to O, Ru, Ni, Mo, and P. Notably, the high intensity of the Ni and Mo signals indicated a concentration gradient or a compositional stratification within the nanopillar. Conversely, the signals for Ru and P were subdued, suggesting that these elements may be present in low concentrations or occupied thin layers within the hierarchical structure. Complementary to the line scans, the EDS elemental maps for Ni, Mo, O, P, and Ru offer spatial resolution of the elemental distribution. Ni and O demonstrated a wide distribution, highlighting their importance as key components of the core and shell of the nanopillar framework. The localized intensities observed in the Mo maps revealed areas of elevated concentration at the core of nanopillars, whereas the P and Ru maps revealed areas of low distribution, which suggested that these elements were present in low concentrations. These trends provided insight into the material's unique compositional architecture. Moreover, Fig. S5(c) and Table S1 present the EDS spectrum and analysis for the Ru-NiMoO4@Ni3(PO4)2 nanopillars. The data revealed the percentages in terms of mass and atomic fractions, indicating a minimal incorporation of Ru within the structure. ICP analysis was conducted, as documented in Table S2, to quantify the elemental mass fractions. The results of ICP analysis were consistent with the findings of EDS, further proving the limited extent of Ru doping. The integration of HAADF imaging with EDS mapping and line scans delivered a comprehensive portrayal of the nanopillars’ intricate interplay between structure and composition. This multimodal analytical approach elucidates the complex hierarchical organization and elemental synergy within Ru-NiMoO4@Ni3(PO4)2 nanopillars, contributing valuable information for the optimization of their functional properties in potential applications ranging from catalysis to energy storage systems. The XRD spectra of the synthesized Ru-NiMoO4@Ni3(PO4)2/ NF composites are presented in Fig. 2(a) . Analysis of the XRD spectra revealed prominent diffraction peaks at 2θ values of 44.83°, 52.22°, and 76.8°, which belonged to the (111), (200), and (220) lattice planes of the metallic nickel substrate. This correlation was substantiated by Powder Diffraction File (PDF) #03-1051. Furthermore, diffraction peaks observed at 17.54°, 25.99°, and 37.19° were attributed to the (002), (111), and (200) planes of Ni3(PO4)2, respectively, as validated by PDF #01-070-1796 [25], exhibited monoclinic crystal geometry. The remaining peaks were consistent with those of nickel molybdate hexahydrate (NiMoO4·nH2O), indicating the material's crystalline formation. This crystallization pattern, referencing PDF #04-017-0338, exhibited a triclinic (anorthic) crystal geometry, which was aligned with findings previously reported in the literature [30,41,42]. A comparative analysis of the XRD spectra of the Ru-NiMoO4@Ni3(PO4)2/NF sample, NiMoO4@Ni3(PO4)2/NF and NiMoO4/NF (depicted in Fig. S3) suggested the successful incorporation of Ru and Ni3(PO4)2 into the hydrous NiMoO4 lattice. This conclusion was drawn from the observed spectral variations between these samples, indicating a distinct structural integration within the Ru-NiMoO4@Ni3(PO4)2/NF composite. To explore the alterations in surface functional groups and structural shifts during the activation procedure, we conducted Raman spectroscopic evaluations on NiMoO4/NF, NiMoO4@Ni3(PO4)2/NF, and Ru-NiMoO4@Ni3(PO4)2/NF. The resultant spectra are shown in Fig. 2(b). We initiated our discussion by examining the Raman scattering resulting from NiMoO4 vibrations, which were observed consistently across all specimens before and after Ru and phosphate doping. The vibrational peaks detected at 950, 896, and 821 cm−1 could be linked to the symmetrical and anti-symmetrical stretching motions of the Mo–O bonds. By contrast, the resonances identified at 344, 356, and 370 cm−1 originated from the bending oscillations of the Mo–O bond [20,30,43,44]. The vibrational mode at 872 cm−1 in NiMoO4 and 884 cm−1 after doping were linked to the asymmetric stretching interactions of oxygen within the Mo=O bond [30], whereas the resonance at 211 cm−1 was due to the bending motions of the Mo−O−Mo linkage [43]. The vibrational band at 787 cm−1 corresponded to the symmetrical stretching dynamics of the Ni−O−Mo linkage [43,45]. Notably, the Raman resonances observed for the hydrated variants were consistent with established findings in the literature. After phosphorylation, NiMoO4@Ni3(PO4)2/NF and Ru-NiMoO4@ Ni3(PO4)2/NF exhibited novel vibrational modes attributed to internal (PO4)3− and external oscillations, respectively. The distinct oxo-anion (PO4)3− vibrational modes encompassed a singlet (A1) at ν 1 = 940 cm−1 and ν 2 = 532 cm−1 and set of triply degenerate modes at ν 3 = 1042 cm−1. Within these, ν1 and ν3 were related to the symmetric and asymmetric stretching of P−O bonds, whereas ν2 primarily represented O−P−O symmetric and asymmetric bending with minor P oscillation [46–48]. The Raman resonances around 640 and 677 cm−1 were due to of the Ni–O stretching mode. Given that this band's frequency corresponded to the divalent transition-metal cation's ionic radius, we hypothesized that elements from the (PO4)3− played a role in this movement. Moreover, novel peaks at 726 and 192 cm−1 were linked to the asymmetric stretching and bending dynamics of the Mo–O–Mo bond. The vibrations at 284 and 301 cm−1 were associated with Mo–O [43,49], and the new vibrational resonance at 484 cm−1 is indicative of Mo=O [20]. The incorporation of phosphate into NiMoO4 led to structural and electronic disruptions, influencing the local bonding of molybdenum and oxygen. This phenomenon resulted in the emergence of novel vibrational modes, which were primarily associated with Mo–O, Mo–O–Mo, and Mo=O interactions. Specific vibrational modes displayed frequency shifts. These alterations could be attributed to the influence of phosphate on bond lengths, angles, and coordination configurations surrounding Mo and Ni, subsequently modifying the observed vibrational properties of the Raman spectrum. The Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) spectra of the hydrated NiMoO4, NiMoO4@Ni3(PO4)2/NF and Ru-NiMoO4@Ni3(PO4)2/NF are depicted in Fig. 2(c). The FTIR spectra of Ru-NiMoO4@Ni3(PO4)2/NF and NiMoO4@Ni3(PO4)2/NF exhibited distinct bands characteristic of the phosphate group. The vibrational modes of the phosphate group (PO4)3− were observed in the following order. The symmetric stretching mode, ν1, was evident in the bands at 818, 848, and 911 cm−1. The ν 2 bending mode was represented by peaks at 467 cm−1. For the ν3 asymmetric stretching mode, diverse peaks were observed at 1030, 1098, 1249, and 1316 cm−1, indicating the potential influence of specific molecular interactions or environments on the phosphate group. Lastly, the peaks at 644 cm−1 corresponded to the ν 4 bending mode [48,50]. In addition to the phosphate signatures, the presence of Ni–O bands at 496 and 515 cm−1, Mo–O at 597 cm−1 [51], and Mo=O at 887 and 965 cm−1 encompassed symmetrical and antisymmetric stretching modes [52], and the symmetrical stretching of the Mo–O–Ni at 742 and 778 cm−1 proved the structural integration of these elements in the synthesized compounds [30]. The range between 1500 and 1750 cm−1, associated with δH2O, suggested the presence of adsorbed or coordinated water molecules [30,53]. Interestingly, compared with the hydrous nature of NiMoO4, the FT-IR values for Ni–O, Mo–O, Mo=O, and Mo–O–Ni were similar. However, a slight vibrational shift was evident after phosphorylation and Ru doping. This shift highlighted the slight changes in the molecular environment induced by these modifications, which may influence the physicochemical properties and performance of the materials in their intended applications. The XPS analysis of the Ru-NiMoO4@Ni3(PO4)2, NiMoO4@Ni3(PO4)2, and NiMoO4 electrocatalysts provided valuable insights into the surface chemistry and electronic structure of the material (Fig. S6(a)). The Ru-NiMoO4@Ni3(PO4)2/NF electrocatalyst was analyzed via XPS analysis. The investigation began with the examination of the full survey spectra to obtain a deep understanding (Fig. 3(a) ) of the elemental composition of the material. The spectra provided a clear representation of the elemental makeup, which included Ni 2p, Mo 3d, O 1s, Ru 3p, C 1s, and P 2p. These compositions are essential for understanding the catalytic nature of the material. The spectrum analysis of the Ru-NiMoO4@Ni3(PO4)2 compound demonstrated unique peaks corresponding to various oxidation states of Ru, specifically observed in the core-level peaks of Ru 3p. These findings are illustrated in Fig. 3(b). Peaks appearing at 461.22 and 482.78 eV could be assigned to the Ru0 3p 3/2 and Ru0 3p 1/2 states, respectively, thereby confirming the existence of metallic ruthenium. Concurrently, the resonances observed at 468.25 and 491.92 eV were related to the Ru3+ 3p 3/2 and Ru3+ 3p 1/2 states, respectively [54–56]. For comparison, the precursor material, RuCl3·xH2O, was also analyzed, where Ru was primarily in the +3 oxidation state. The positive shift in binding energy of Ru3+ in the catalyst but same oxidation state suggested successful Ru doping. This shift could be explained by changes in the electronic environment around Ru, such as altered coordination, electronegative neighbors, or strain effects in the catalyst matrix, which can impact its catalytic properties. The C 1s + Ru 3d spectra exhibited peaks at different binding energies, representing carbon and ruthenium species (Fig. S6(b)). The peaks at 279.58 and 283.80 eV were attributed to Ru 3d 5/2 and Ru 3d 3/2, respectively, indicating the presence of ruthenium in its metallic state. The peaks at 280.45 and 284.98 eV represented Ru2+ 3d 5/2 and Ru2+ 3d 3/2, respectively, suggesting the presence of ruthenium in the +2 oxidation state [55,57,58]. The XPS spectrum of P 2p for the Ru-NiMoO4@Ni3(PO4)2 sample displayed a sharp and well-defined peak at 134 eV (Fig. 3(c)), which was a characteristic indicator of the presence of phosphorus in the form of phosphate (PO4)3– groups [29,59,60]. The peak was symmetric and the fitted data closely matched the raw data points, indicating a single chemical state for the element and confirming the reliability of the peak assignment. The presence of the phosphate group in the catalyst structure can impact the electronic structure of the surrounding metal atoms by altering their oxidation state or by affecting the distribution of electron density. Phosphate groups can also provide sites for adsorption or interaction with reactant molecules, which can be crucial for catalytic processes. The Ni 2p spectra exhibited peaks corresponding to various oxidation states of nickel (Fig. 3(d)). The peaks at binding energies of 852.48 and 873.45 eV corresponded to Ni0 2p 3/2 and Ni0 2p 1/2, respectively, indicating the presence of metallic nickel. The peaks at 856.36 and 874.65 eV represented Ni2+ 2p 3/2 and Ni2+ 2p 1/2, respectively, suggesting the presence of nickel in the +2 oxidation state. Similarly, peaks at 857.90 and 877.32 eV were attributed to Ni3+ 2p 3/2 and Ni3+ 2p 1/2, respectively, indicating the presence of nickel in the +3 oxidation state [61]. Nickel in its metallic state could provide electron-rich sites for adsorption and activation of reactant molecules, while the oxidized forms Ni2+ and Ni3+ could participate in electron exchange during catalysis. This multiplicity of accessible oxidation states within the electrocatalyst points to a surface that can support a range of catalytic activities, possibly facilitating the oxidation and reduction steps in reaction cycles. The Mo 3d spectrum unveiled oxidation states for Mo (Mo6+, Mo5+, Mo4+, and Mo0), suggesting a surface rich in redox-active sites (Fig. 3(e)). The peaks at 232.4 and 235.37 eV corresponded to Mo6+ 3d 5/2 and Mo6+ 3d 3/2, respectively, indicating the presence of molybdenum in its hexavalent state. The peaks at 231.06 and 233.94 eV represented Mo5+ 3d 5/2 and Mo5+ 3d 3/2, respectively, suggesting the presence of molybdenum in its pentavalent and tetravalent states. Similarly, peaks at 229.85 and 233 eV were attributed to Mo4+ 3d 5/2 and Mo4+ 3d 3/2, respectively [20,59]. Lastly, the peaks at 228.78 and 231.8 eV reflected Mo0 3d 5/2 and Mo0 3d 3/2, respectively. The positive shift in binding energy for the Ru-NiMoOx@Ni3(PO4)2/NF sample relative to the NiMoO4/NF sample was a clear indication of electronic perturbation due to the addition of Ru and phosphate, which may influence the catalytic activity and stability of the material. The O 1s spectra exhibited characteristic peaks at various binding energies, corresponding to different oxygen species (Fig. 3(f)). The presence of four distinct peaks at 530.8, 531.5, 532.58, and 533.49 eV was attributed to metal-oxygen (M−O) bonds, oxygen vacancies (V0), P−O bonds, and H−O−H species, respectively. The peak at 530.8 eV for M−O bonds in Ru-NiMoO4@Ni3(PO4)2 indicated robust metal-oxygen interactions within the material in accordance with previously reported values for metal oxides [25]. Interestingly, this peak aligned precisely with that observed for NiMoO4@Ni3(PO4)2, suggesting that the introduction of Ru did not disrupt the native M−O bonding environment in the composite. Notably, the Ru dopants were successfully integrated into the NiMoO4 matrix without causing strain or altering the essential metal-oxygen bonding characteristics, which could be essential for catalytic activities where metal-oxygen bonds play a critical role. Lastly, the peak attributed to H−O−H in Ru-NiMoO4@Ni3(PO4)2 and NiMoO4@Ni3(PO4)2 demonstrated that NiMoO4 maintained its hydrous nature after doping. Integrating the data from individual spectra analyses, we proved that the Ru-NiMoO4@Ni3(PO4)2/NF electrocatalyst possessed a complex surface with a multifaceted electronic structure. The interplay of various oxidation states, alongside the incorporation of Ru and (PO4)3– groups, suggested that the material was engineered to offer numerous active sites and a rich redox chemistry. This complexity translated to enhanced catalytic performance. Each element results in the overall activity of the catalyst, with synergistic effects contributing to the high effectiveness ofthe Ru-NiMoO4@Ni3(PO4)2/NF system. 3.2 Electrocatalytic evaluation Before conducting HER, OER, and overall water splitting tests, the catalysts were activated and surface pollution was removed after 100 cycles of cyclic voltammetry (CV) at a scan rate of 50 mV s−1. The performance of the prepared samples was evaluated in 1.0 mol L−1 KOH solution at room temperature at a scan rate of 2 mV s−1, applying IR compensation. Testing was conducted using a typical three-electrode apparatus for HER and OER and two-electrode system for overall water splitting. 3.2.1 HER catalytic performance The electrochemical performance of the as-synthesized Ru-NiMoO4@Ni3(PO4)2/NF nanopillars was extensively examined and benchmarked against several control nanopillars, including Ru-NiMoO4/NF, NiMoO4@Ni3(PO4)2/NF, and NiMoO4/NF, as well as Pt/C/NF and bare NF. Among all these prepared electrodes, the LSV for the Ru-NiMoO4@Ni3(PO4)2/NF nanopillar electrode showed the highest performance toward HER with an overpotential of 14.81 mV at a current density of 10 mA cm−2 (Fig. 4(a) ). Fig. 4(b) displays the operating overpotentials of different catalysts at current densities of 10 and 100 mA cm−2. The synergy resulting from Ru doping and phosphorylation on hydrous NiMoO4/NF and the HER activity of Ru-NiMoO4@Ni3(PO4)2/NF further improved significantly due to the introduction of new active sites, the optimization of hydrogen binding energy, and enhanced charge transport. A systematic study was further conducted to determine the influence of immersion time on the catalyst performance of the Ru-NiMoO4@Ni3(PO4)2/NF nanopillars. The NiMoO4/NF nanopillars were immersed in RuCl3·xH2O solution, with a concentration of 2 mg mL−1, for varying durations (15, 30, and 45 min and 1, 3, 4 and 5 h). As shown in the LSV curves in Fig. S7(a) and in the overpotential results in Table S5, at the standard immersion time of 2 h, the electrochemical behavior was still the best among the tested immersion times. Meanwhile, short immersion periods showed low catalytic performance because the amount of deposited Ru was insufficient for uniform and precise distribution throughout the catalyst, and long immersion periods showed low performance due to undesirable Ru deposit. These trends emphasized the importance of immersion time for regulating doping and improving the electrochemical activity of nanopillars. Furthermore, the RuCl3·xH2O solution concentration emerged as a factor influencing the Ru-NiMoO4@Ni3(PO4)2/NF catalyst's electrochemical characteristics. When the concentration was amplified to 6 and 10 mg mL−1 at a fixed immersion time of 2 h, the results exhibited low performance compared with the standard concentration of 2 mg mL−1 (Fig. S7(c) and Table S7), which was attributed to the accumulation of Ru and the formation of large grains, which affected the active sites and performance. These results emphasized the intricate balance required in solution concentration to obtain the desired electrochemical response. In assessing the HER kinetics, a Tafel plot was generated from the derived polarization curves, where the Tafel slope provides insight into the reaction mechanism of HER at the catalyst surface. The theoretical Tafel slopes for the Volmer, Heyrovsky, and Tafel steps in HER are 120, 40, and 30 mV dec−1, respectively [62]. A notably reduced Tafel slope was observed for the Ru-NiMoO4@Ni3(PO4)2/NF electrode at 35.82 mV dec−1, suggesting that the etching of ultralow Ru and subsequent phosphorylation treatment effectively enhanced the kinetics of water dissociation. As a result, the rate-determining step of HER transitioned from the Volmer step to the Heyrovsky step. By contrast, the Pt/C/NF, Ru-NiMoO4/NF, NiMoO4@Ni3(PO4)2/NF, NiMoO4/NF, and bare NF electrodes showed steep slopes of 66.65, 78.52, 83.4, 116.68, and 127.07 mV dec−1, respectively, as depicted in Fig. 4(c). These outcomes accentuated the superior HER kinetic performance of the Ru-NiMoO4@Ni3(PO4)2/NF electrode relative to its counterparts. Furthermore, the Ru-NiMoO4@Ni3(PO4)2/NF electrode's exceptional kinetics under the chosen immersion time and solution concentration (2 h and 2 mg mL−1) proved to be unparalleled. When the immersion time was varied to high and low durations, the kinetics observed under the initial condition remained superior (Fig. S7(b)). Similarly, whether the concentration of the immersion solution was increased, the Ru-NiMoO4@Ni3(PO4)2/NF electrode exhibited the best HER kinetics at the originally chosen concentration (Fig. S7(d)). The presented findings suggested a notable enhancement in the electron transfer process, which expedited the HER kinetics during the regulation doping of Ru and phosphorylation. This process improved the innate activity of the electrocatalyst. A promising finding was that Ru-NiMoO4@Ni3(PO4)2/NF was superior to most reported catalysts in HER tests (Fig. 4(d) and Table S12). EIS facilitated the examination of the charge transfer process, with the Nyquist plots being represented using an equivalent circuit. This circuit encompassed a charge-transfer resistance (R ct), a solution resistance (R s), and a constant phase element, as illustrated in Figs. 4(e) and S8. Through the CV method (Fig. S9), the electrochemical double-layer capacitance (C dl) was determined across a non-Faradaic potential range to gauge the electrochemically active surface area (ECSA) of the newly prepared catalysts. Distinct C dl values, derived from CV curves at varied scan rates, were observed for NiMoO4/NF, Ru-NiMoO4/NF, NiMoO4@Ni3(PO4)2/NF, and Ru-NiMoO4@Ni3(PO4)2/NF at 11.44, 20.22, 92.5, and 138.73 mF cm−2, respectively (Fig. 4(f)). Furthermore, under diverse immersion times (Fig. S11), Ru-NiMoO4@Ni3(PO4)2/NF consistently showcased the most elevated C dl values relative to the Ru-NiMoO4@Ni3(PO4)2/NF benchmark. This result suggested that precise management of dual doping could enhance the active site count, thereby optimizing the HER and OER kinetics. By normalizing the LSV curves to ECSA, our results proved that Ru-NiMoO4@Ni3(PO4)2/NF possessed superior intrinsic HER activity compared with the other synthesized samples (Fig. S10). Multistep chronopotentiometry revealed that Ru-NiMoO4@Ni3(PO4)2/NF exhibited outstanding mass transport and electrical conductivity throughout the HER process (Fig. 4(g)). Beyond catalytic activity, stability and durability remain pivotal in evaluating the real-world utility of an efficient electrocatalyst. Thus, a durability test was conducted at a potential of −57 mV versus RHE (at current density of ≈100 mA cm−2) over 100 h (Fig. 4(h)). This analysis underscores the exceptional stability and durability of the Ru-NiMoO4@Ni3(PO4)2/NF nanopillars in an alkaline context. Furthermore, after the durability test, the polarization curve of Ru-NiMoO4@Ni3(PO4)2/NF displayed negligible degradation (inset of Fig. 4(h)). 3.2.2 OER catalytic performance Within the evaluation of Ru-NiMoO4@Ni3(PO4)2/NF nanopillars, the electrochemical performance for OER was thoroughly investigated. Fig. 5(a) shows that the LSV of the Ru-NiMoO4@Ni3(PO4)2/NF catalyst required an overpotential of 259.7 mV at 100 mA cm−2. This overpotential performance significantly improved compared with that of NiMoO4@Ni3(PO4)2/NF (315.7 mV), Ru-NiMoO4/NF (384.7 mV), RuO2/NF (350.3 mV), NiMoO4/NF (406.2 mV), and bare NF (579.1 mV) at a current density of 100 mA cm−2. The differential overpotential values of these catalysts at various current densities, ranging from 100 to 300 mA cm−2, are detailed in Fig. 5(b) and Table 8. The immersion times and solution concentrations were also varied to determine their influence on the OER performance of the catalyst. Figs. S12(a) and S12(c) confirmed that the standard Ru-NiMoO4@Ni3(PO4)2/NF condition (2 mg mL−1 and 2 h) offered optimal OER performance. Further data regarding these variations are detailed in Tables S10 and S11. In the LSV results, distinct oxidation peaks are observed. These peaks can be attributed to the fact that NiMoO4·nH2O is a supercapacitor material with an oxidation peak between 0.4 and 0.6 V. One possible explanation for these peaks is the oxidation of water to oxygen. Additionally, the peaks may be connected to the electrochemical oxidation of nickel ions within the catalyst. In nickel molybdate structures, nickel ions exist in different oxidation states. When an electrical potential is applied, these nickel ions transition from a lower to a higher oxidation state (such as Ni2+ to Ni3+ or Ni4+), facilitating the oxygen evolution reaction. The role of molybdenum is also crucial in this context. Molybdenum can influence the electronic structure of the catalyst, potentially creating active sites or altering the dynamics of nickel's oxidation states, which contributes to the observed peak. Furthermore, the use of NF as a substrate is significant. If the catalyst does not fully cover NF, a pronounced peroxide peak may occur, which has been documented in several related studies [29,30]. The Tafel slope, which provides insights into OER kinetics, for the Ru-NiMoO4@Ni3(PO4)2/NF electrode was determined to be 21.57 mV dec−1 (Fig. 5(c)), indicating a favorable OER reaction kinetic for the Ru-NiMoO4@Ni3(PO4)2/NF electrode in comparison with the reported electrocatalysts. The specific values and trends related to different immersion times and RuCl3·xH2O concentrations can be found in Figs. S12(b) and S12(d) and Tables S10 and S11. At the standard Ru-NiMoO4@Ni3(PO4)2/NF condition (2 mg mL−1, 2 h), electrode had the lowest Tafel slope value. An encouraging result revealed that Ru-NiMoO4@Ni3(PO4)2/NF outperformed the majority of catalysts previously documented in OER experiments, as shown in Fig. 5(d) and Table S13. EIS was employed to gain further insights into the charge transfer processes during OER. Figs. 5(e) and S14 present the Nyquist plots, showcasing the intricate relationship among charge-transfer resistance (R ct), solution resistance (R s), and a constant phase element. A noticeable reduction in R ct was observed, pointing to an enhanced OER catalytic efficiency. The durability of Ru-NiMoO4@Ni3(PO4)2/NF under OER conditions has been observed to maintain a stable potential of 259.7 mV versus RHE over 50 h, as depicted in Fig. 5(f), and the inset of Fig. 5(f) shows the LSV polarization curves after durability testing and across 3000 cycles. It is important to note that during the stability test at 100 mA cm−2, the current density decreases from 100 to 90.77 mA cm−2 at a degradation rate of 0.186 mA cm−2 h−1, which still falls within the acceptable range when compared to similar studies [22,63–67]. Enhancing the stability of such catalysts in OER applications remains a valuable direction for future work. The after stability testing of the Ru-NiMoO4@Ni3(PO4)2 core-shell for HER and OER was thoroughly assessed using XRD, Raman spectroscopy, and XPS analyses, as shown in Figs. S14–S16, respectively. The XRD pattern after stability testing of HER and OER exhibits consistent characteristic peaks of both NiMoO4 and Ni3(PO4)2, with no significant shift, indicating the preservation of the crystalline structure (Fig. S14). Raman spectroscopy (Fig. S15) further supports this finding, with the vibrational modes of the phosphate groups and the molybdate units remaining pronounced and unchanged after stability testing for both HER and OER, indicating the preservation of the chemical framework of NiMoO4 and Ni3(PO4)2. XPS measurements (Fig. S16) demonstrate that the elemental composition and chemical states remained consistent after stability testing of HER and OER, implying the stability of the composite under both reductive and oxidative conditions. The observed negative shift for Ni and Mo subsequent to the HER and OER reactions denotes a temporary reduction in the levels of Ni and Mo during the course of HER and OER. Additionally, the slight variations in the signals of Ni and Mo serve to validate the persistent stability of the Ru-NiMoO4@Ni3(PO4)2/NF electrode [68]. These characterizations collectively affirm the structural integrity and compositional stability of both the nickel molybdate core and the nickel phosphate shell throughout electrochemical testing. Upon evaluating the catalytic efficiency of the hydrous NiMoO4/NF and Ru-NiMoO4@Ni3(PO4)2/NF specimens, that the combination of Ru doping and phosphate coating improved the performance of the nanopillars. On the one hand, the presence of nanopillars amplified the surface area, resulting in a rise in active sites conducive for OER. On the other hand, the combination of Ru doping and phosphate coating bolstered the conductivity, reduced R ct, inhibited the breakdown tendencies of the nanopillars, and facilitated the formation of an efficacious electron transfer structure. Such modifications are pivotal for optimizing OER outcomes. Additionally, the hydrous attribute of NiMoO4 played an indispensable role in bolstering OER performance. In the hydrous NiMoO4 compound, two distinct categories of water molecules exist: those present on the surface and those coordinated within the structure [41]. Upon subjecting the material to temperatures beyond 100 °C, we observed a marked elimination of surface water, which may comprise a fraction of the lattice water. However, in the studied specimen, coordination-bound water molecules remained unaffected even after undergoing an annealing process up to 300 °C. Notably, this annealing procedure at 300 °C did not alter the catalytic efficacy related to OER. In previous research, when samples were annealed at 550 °C, the hydrous form transformed into a purely crystalline NiMoO4 structure, accompanying a significant reduction in performance. This degradation, primarily evident as a reduction in current density, was linked to an increased oxygen presence, leading to a decrease in the surface irregularities or active sites that are crucial for the amplification of catalytic processes [30]. Comparable observations of diminishing catalytic activity in correlation with elevated temperatures have been noted in other oxide materials, including Ru2O [69], and Mn2O3 [70], which can be attributed to excessive oxygen ingress. Thus, the pronounced catalytic activity was attributed to the intrinsic hydrous nature of NiMoO4. The integration of Ru and (PO4)3− into the nanostructure also showed a similar pattern, with a decrease in overpotential [56]. The intrinsic characteristics of hydrous NiMoO4, such as a high concentration of active surface sites and a unique nanopillar morphology, contribute to the enhancement of electrochemical outcomes. Simultaneously, the introduction of Ru enhanced the system's electrical conductivity, as reflected by the reduced R ct. The combination of these characteristics resulted in an overall improvement in performance, thereby demonstrating the synergistic interaction among hydrous NiMoO4, Ru doping, and phosphate coating. 3.2.3 Overall water splitting Following the impressive catalytic capabilities demonstrated for both OER and HER in 1 mol L−1 KOH solutions, we further explored the efficacy of Ru-NiMoO4@Ni3(PO4)2/NF in water splitting by utilizing it as the anode and cathode within a two-electrode framework. Fig. 6(a) provides both a visual and schematic representation detailing the setup for the overall water splitting electrolyzer. Within this image, the emergence of gas bubbles from each electrode was evident. For evaluation, we initially adopted ΔV (defined as ΔV = V η, HER + V η, OER) as a parameter to determine the combined performance of the bifunctional catalysts addressing HER and OER. The calculated ΔV for Ru-NiMoO4@Ni3(PO4)2/NF was determined to be 1.64 V at a current density of 100 mA cm−2. In a detailed electrochemical examination of overall water splitting, as depicted in Fig. 6(b), the assembled Ru-NiMoO4@Ni3(PO4)2/NF||Ru-NiMoO4@ Ni3(PO4)2/NF system efficiently produced current densities of 10 and 100 mA cm−2 at cell voltages of 1.43 and 1.68 V, respectively. Notably, when compared with several esteemed self-supported materials in a 1 mol L−1 KOH context (Fig. 6(c) and Table S15), the voltage for overall water splitting at 10 mA cm−2 employing Ru-NiMoO4@Ni3(PO4)2/NF||Ru-NiMoO4@ Ni3(PO4)2/NF was lower, proving the superiority of Ru-NiMoO4@Ni3(PO4)2/NF as an exceptional bifunctional catalyst suitable for the generation of H2 and O2. Durability, a critical parameter for evaluating electrolyzer efficiency, is emphasized in Fig. 6(d). This electrolyzer consistently demonstrated outstanding performance in overall water splitting, even after 150 h of continuous operation in an alkaline solution (1 mol L−1 KOH) with almost negligible degradation and a modest voltage increase of less than 10% to maintain a current density of 100 mA cm−2. Fig. S17 displays the SEM images following the durability study, illustrating the catalyst's sustained nanopillar structure, which indicated its structural integrity during prolonged stability measurements. The electrochemical workstation was connected to a gas chromatograph Faraday efficiency (FE) test, which evaluated the production of H2 and O2 gas evolution in situ during the water splitting process. As illustrated in Fig. 6(e), the Ru-NiMoO4@Ni3(PO4)2/NF catalyst demonstrated FEs of 97.12% ± 0.20% for H2 and 94.8% ± 0.20% for O2 across various current densities (20, 60, 100, 140, and 180 mA). These findings highlight the catalyst's high efficiency in water splitting and its effective electron utilization. 3.3 DFT calculations In the initial step of our DFT calculations, we introduced four thoughtfully designed models, each representing a distinct site: a hydrated nickel molybdate (NiMoO4·nH2O), a ruthenium-doped hydrated nickel molybdate (Ru-NiMoO4·nH2O), a hydrated nickel molybdate core encased in a nickel phosphate shell (NiMoO4·nH2O@Ni3(PO4)2), and a ruthenium-doped hydrated nickel molybdate core with a nickel phosphate shell (Ru-NiMoO4·nH2O@Ni3(PO4)2), as depicted in Fig. 7(a) . Also, Fig. S18 depicts the adsorption models corresponding to each composite. To investigate the effect of Ru doping and phosphate coating on the NiMoO4·nH2O catalyst, we proposed that Ru [56] atoms and (PO4)3− [25] ions enhance the catalyst's effectiveness. When Ru and (PO4)3− are introduced through doping and phosphate coating respectively, they are hypothesized to act as more efficient bifunctional sites for the HER and OER processes than the traditional Ni and Mo sites. For HER catalysts, a hydrogen absorption energy (ΔG *H) near zero exhibits exceptional catalytic behavior. As shown in Fig. 7(b), the ΔG *H values for the four catalysts were computed to assess the synergistic enhancement from the incorporation of Ru and Ni3(PO4)2. ΔG *H for Ru-NiMoO4·nH2O@Ni3(PO4)2, NiMoO4·nH2O@Ni3(PO4)2, Ru-NiMoO4·nH2O, and NiMoO4·nH2O was −0.02, −0.13, 0.15 and 0.38 eV, respectively. Remarkably, ΔG *H of Ru-NiMoO4·nH2O@Ni3(PO4)2, which was closest to zero, indicated its superior hydrogen adsorption capability, a key indicator of its enhanced catalytic potential in HER processes. For OER (Fig. 7(c)), the energetic variations for four potential sites (OH*, O*, OOH*, and O2+*) were computed. The ΔG *OOH – ΔG *OH free energy values for adsorption on an electrocatalyst are crucial for OER performance, providing key thermodynamic insights into the interactions between intermediates and the electrocatalyst. Very strong or weak bonding can impede reactions [1,71]. The Ru-NiMoO4·nH2O@Ni3(PO4)2 electrocatalyst exhibited a reduction in ΔG *OOH – ΔG *OH of 2.74 eV compared whit 2.89 eV for NiMoO4·nH2O@Ni3(PO4)2, 3.02 eV for Ru-NiMoO4·nH2O, and 3.07 eV for NiMoO4·nH2O. These values suggested that the integration of Ru doping and phosphate coating on the NiMoO4·nH2O catalyst was an effective strategy for enhancing the water-to-oxygen conversion efficiency. In Fig. 7(d), our calculations showed that the Gibbs free energy (ΔG b) for water dissociation on NiMoO4·nH2O was 1.04 eV. This value decreased to 0.9 eV with the doping of Ru on NiMoO4·nH2O. The addition of a Ni3(PO4)2 shell at the NiMoO4·nH2O core further lowered ΔG b to 0.59 eV. Notably, the combination of Ru doping and phosphate coating resulted in ΔG b of 0.46 eV, indicating a synergistic effect that enhanced the catalytic activity. The electronic structures of NiMoO4·nH2O and Ru-NiMoO4·nH2O, as well as their respective phosphate interactions, were examined to reveal changes in their density of states (DOS) and projected density of states (PDOSs), as shown in Figs. 7(e)–7(h). The integration of these measurements indicated a deliberate change in the electronic configuration from the undoped NiMoO4·nH2O sample to the Ru-doped variant and their interactions with phosphate groups. Ru doping introduced additional electronic states that enhanced the material's catalytic properties, as shown in Figs. 7(e) and 7(f). Furthermore, the presence of phosphate groups, as observed in Figs. 7(g) and 7(h), provided novel active sites and a high DOS close to the Fermi level, thereby enhancing electrical conductivity for electron transfer in catalytic applications. The DOS and PDOS analyses demonstrated that Ru incorporation and phosphate interaction played crucial roles in tailoring the electronic properties of NiMoO4·nH2O. 4 Conclusions In our study, we discovered that the exceptional capabilities of the Ru-NiMoO4@Ni3(PO4)2/NF core-shell structure in OER and HER processes, along with its remarkable stability over prolonged operational periods. Compared with other self-supported materials, the catalytic performance of NiMoO4@Ni3(PO4)2/NF was found to outperform many of its counterparts. Moreover, the catalyst reconstruction process plays an integral role in retaining optimal catalytic activity. This optimization was further bolstered by the seamless interface between NF and NiMoO4, complemented by the synergistic Ru doping and phosphate coating. The adopted chemical growth process for the formation of nanopillars led to strong covalent bonding between the nickel surface and Mo and Ni precursors, which facilitated uniform, vertically oriented nanopillar growth. Furthermore, the hydrous character of NiMoO4, in tandem with the well-distributed Ru and Ni3(PO4)2, amplified the catalyst's efficiency. Electrochemical tests revealed an impressive overall water splitting efficiency, with the system achieving desired cell voltages at relatively low current densities. Durability tests further validated the catalyst's potential, displaying minimal degradation over 150 h of continuous operation. Subsequently, DFT calculations were conducted, which confirmed these practical observations by revealing exceptionally low adsorption free energy for hydrogen, minimal Gibbs free energy for OER and water dissociation, and the presence of innovative active sites with elevated density state near the Fermi level. These theoretical insights not only validated the empirical performance of the Ru-NiMoO4@Ni3(PO4)2 core-shell composite but also emphasized its potential for sustainable hydrogen production through water splitting. These observations demonstrated that NiMoO4@Ni3(PO4)2/NF emerges as a promising bifunctional catalyst for water electrolysis, offering new avenues for efficient and sustainable hydrogen production. This research provides meaningful insights for the continued exploration and development of efficient catalysts for sustainable hydrogen production. coredata.dc:description: The potential of sustainable hydrogen production technology through water splitting necessitates the rational design of oxygen evolution reaction (OER) and hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) bi-functional electrocatalysts. In this context, we initially synthesized and empirically evaluated ultralow Ru-doped NiMoO4@Ni3(PO4)2 core-shell nanostructures on nickel foam (Ru-NiMoO4@Ni3(PO4)2/NF). The hydrous NiMoO4 nanopillars were hydrothermally grown on NF, followed by successive RuCl3 etching and subsequent phosphorylation processes, leading to the final Ru-NiMoO4@Ni3(PO4)2/NF. The catalyst demonstrated impressive HER overpotential values of −14.8 and −57.1 mV at 10 and 100 mA cm−2, respectively, with a Tafel slope of 35.8 mV dec−1. For OER at 100 mA cm−2, an overpotential of 259.7 mV was observed, with a Tafel slope of 21.6 mV dec−1. The cell voltage required for overall water splitting was 1.43 V at 10 mA cm−2 and 1.68 V at 100 mA cm−2. Moreover, the catalyst exhibited superior stability for 150 h, emphasizing its practical utility for long-term applications. Subsequent density functional theory calculations aligned with these empirical findings, indicating a low water dissociation energy barrier (ΔG b = 0.46 eV), near-zero free adsorption energy for HER (ΔG *H = 0.02 eV), and suitable free adsorption energy for OER (ΔG *OOH − ΔG *OH = 2.74 eV), alongside a high density of states near the Fermi level. These results, informed by both experimental evaluation and theoretical validation, highlight the potential of Ru-NiMoO4@Ni3(PO4)2/NF as a high-performance catalyst for water splitting, setting a solid foundation for advancements in sustainable energy technologies.
